Title:
Taxonomy and phylogeny of Phellinidium (Hymenochaetales,
Basidiomycota): a redefinition and the segregation of Coniferiporia gen.
nov. for forest pathogens
Abstract:
Phellinidium, which includes 13 accepted polypore species
mostly with resupinate basidiocarps, is one of the most aggressive
forest pathogenic genera. This genus is characterized by the combination
of a monomitic hyphal structure, abundant hyphoid setae in the context
and trama, and hyaline and thin-walled basidiospores. Previously,
nuclear large subunit ribosomal DNA-based phylogenetic analyses
recovered Phellinidium into three clades within Hymenochaetaceae. To
explore the relationships between the species of Phellinidium,
especially those between forest pathogens and saprophytes, we examined
specimens of this genus from Asia, Europe and America from a
morphological and phylogenetic perspective. A new genus, Coniferiporia,
was found to segregate from Phellinidium for three aggressive forest
pathogens, and three new combinations, viz. C. qilianensis (the generic
type), C. weirii and C. sulphurascens, were proposed. Phellinidium
cryptocystidiatum was treated as a synonym of Coniferiporia
sulphurascens. The circumscription of Phellinidium was delimited to
accommodate P. asiaticum, P. ferrugineofuscum (the generic type), P.
fragrans and P. pouzarii. Accordingly, the concept of Phellinidium was
emended. No species of Phellinidium under the new circumscription have
been reported to be forest pathogens. Phellinidium noxium and P.
rufitinctum were excluded from Phellinidium, while the taxonomical
positions of Phellinidium aciferum, P. lamaÃ«nse and P. orientale are
still uncertain. Keys to Coniferiporia and Phellinidium, the three
species of Coniferiporia, and the four accepted species of Phellinidium
are provided.
